columns.text: In this problem, we will determine the break-even quantity of the new policy that was solved for in the previous problem.

In order to get the total revenue for the new policy, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total revenue}&=\dfrac{(\text{Quantity for new policy}-\text{Quantity for current policy})\times(\text{Price per unit}-\text{Cost per unit})}{\text{Required return}}
\end{aligned}$$

Remember that we are solving for the quantity of the new policy, which from this point on will be assigned the variable $Q$, this means that all other variables will have assigned values except for this one.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total revenue}&=\dfrac{(\text{Q}-3,280)\times(\$84-\$47)}{0.023}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{37\times\text{Q}-\$121,360}{0.023}\\[15 pt]
&=1608.70\times \text{Q}-\$5,276,521.74
\end{aligned}$$

We can leave this as is right now since we can no longer simplify it.

Next, we need to solve for the total cost of the policy. In order to do this, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total cost}&=\text{Cost per unit} \times (\text{Q}-\text{Quantity for current policy})\\
&+(\text{Quantity for current policy} \times \text{Price for current policy})
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total cost}&=\$47 \times(\text{Q}-3,280)+(3,280\times \$81)\\[15 pt]
&=\$47\times\text{Q}-\$154,160+\$265,680\\[15 pt]
&=\$47\times\text{Q}+\$111,520
\end{aligned}$$

Since we can no longer simplify this, we can leave it as is.

Now that we have the total revenue and the total cost, we will equate them to each other since an equal cost and revenue means that the net present value is zero. And as we can recall, the break-even point is achieved when the net present value is zero.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total revenue}&=\text{Total cost}\\[15 pt]
1608.70\times \text{Q}-\$5,276,521.74&=\$47\times\text{Q}+\$111,520
\end{aligned}$$

We can then isolate the variable on one side to get its value:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{1608.70}\times\text{Q}-\$47\times\text{Q}&=\$111,520+\$5,276,521.74\\[15 pt]
\$1561.70\times\text{Q}&=\$5,388,041.74\\[15 pt]
\text{Q}&=\dfrac{\$5,388,041.74}{\$1561.70}\\[15 pt]
&=3,450.11
\end{aligned}$$

The break-even quantity for this policy is $3,450.11$
